Graphical abstract Unsupported MoS2 catalysts were obtained by thermal decomposition of ammonium tetrathiomolybdate (ATM) or ammonium heptamolybdate (AHM) using sulfur powder as sulfiding agent at variable sulfidation temperature (400–550°C). The CO conversion, selectivity and yield of CH4 on the catalysts were studied for the methanation reaction. It was found that CO conversion increased with temperature rise at first, reached maximum value at sulfidation temperature of 450°C and then decreased sharply with further increase of temperature. The catalyst derived from ATM could get higher CO conversion than the catalyst from AHM because of the structural similarity between ATM and MoS2. XRD analysis demonstrated that amorphous MoS2 was favorable for the methanation reaction and a crystal transition of MoS2 nanoparticle happened during the methanation reaction. The higher the sulfidation temperature was, the more easily regular crystal structure of MoS2 formed. TEM characterization results showed that at the optimum sulfidation temperature of 450°C, the length and stacking degree of MoS2 crystallite were the highest and so more active sites could reside on the edges of MoS2 slabs for CO methanation. The crystal growth of MoS2 particle and its structure change are probably the reasons for the deactivation of the MoS2 catalysts with the increase of sulfidation temperature. In addition, it is the loss of surface sulfur that caused deactivation of the catalyst with reaction time. Keywords Unsupported catalysts MoS2 Methanation Sulfidation temperature 1 Introduction The use of coal to produce synthetic natural gas (SNG) has been investigated extensively and attracted wide attention recently due to the continuous rising of natural gas price and the concern on the depletion of natural gas [1,2]. Usually, the SNG is produced by gasification of coal [3–7], followed with subsequent methanation process, of which CO methanation is the main reaction. Many metals such as Ni, Co, and Fe, can be used in the methanation reaction [8–10]. But these catalysts are easy to be deactivated at high temperature due to sintering and sulfur poisoning. Molybdenum-based sulfide catalysts, extensively used in the hydrotreating reactions [11–13], have been investigated widely for their insensitivity to sulfur poisoning [14–21] and high activities in the methanation reaction with low H2/CO ratios [22–25]. Previous studies have prepared unsupported molybdenum-based catalysts in laboratory by thermal decomposition of thiosalts [26] and the as-prepared MoS2 catalysts showed good performance. It is generally accepted that the catalytic activity depends greatly on the morphology and the surface structure of the catalysts [27] and the nature of exposed edges depends on the treatment conditions [28]. Based on these discussions, it is necessary to further understand the structural and catalytic properties of unsupported MoS2 particles during the methanation process. Ammonium thiosalts such as ammonium tetrathiomolybdate (ATM) or ammonium heptamolybdate (AHM) usually need to be sulfided/activated at certain temperature to form active MoS2 species [29–31]. The ex situ and in situ activation of the precursors have been studied [14,32–34]. Normally for activation process, 5–20% (vol.%) H2S/H2 was used as sulfiding agent to prepare highly active unsupported MoS2. Other sulfur compounds, such as carbon bisulfide CS2 or carbonyl sulfide COS have been used as well [26]. In a previous study, Pol and his co-workers [35] used sulfur powder instead of toxic H2S to prepare MoS2 or WS2 nanoplates in an inert atmosphere. In the presence of such sulfur powder, the catalytic activity could be enhanced and the deterioration could be prevented. Afanasiev [29] found different morphologies and structures of MoS2 particles obtained under different treatment conditions, corresponding to different catalytic activities. Farag [36] found that sulfidation temperature affected not only the degree of sulfidation but also the crystallinity of MoS2. Okamoto [31] also studied the effect of sulfidation temperature on the structure and HDS activity of SiO2-supported MoS2 catalysts and found that high sulfidation temperature favored the formation of active species. All these previous studies demonstrated that catalysts textural properties and catalytic performance were greatly influenced by treatment conditions, especially sulfidation temperature. In this work, we explored the effect of sulfidation temperature (400–550°C) on the methanation activity of unsupported MoS2 catalysts prepared by using sulfur powder as sulfiding agent. The unsupported MoS2 catalysts were characterized by BET, XRD, HRTEM and LRS. We stressed on getting the structure–activity relationship of the catalyst based on the catalytic activity and stability, textural structure, crystallinity and sulfidation degree of the catalyst, which was assumed being greatly influenced by sulfidation temperature. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation In the present study, we used sulfur powder to prepare the unsupported MoS2 catalysts by thermal decomposition method as described in literature [26]. Sulfur could efficiently make Mo-precursor sulfided to MoS2. Ammonium tetrathiomolybdate (ATM), (NH4)2MoS4 purchased from Alfa Aesar of USA, ammonium heptamolybdate (AHM), (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O from Guang Fu Chemical Agent Company of China and sulfur from Kermel Chemical Agent Company of China were used without further purification. The decomposition was carried out in a quartz tube reactor. The weight ratio of sulfur to Mo-precursor was 3. Sulfur was mixed with ammonium thiosalts in two ways: (a) before mixing, sulfur was heated in a partially covered porcelain dish over a burner. Then ATM or AHM was mixed with molten sulfur, boiling the material to a thick, pasty residue; (b) solid sulfur powder was added to AHM solution. The mixture was stirred and dried in air and then under vacuum at 80°C for about 5h. The above mixtures were charged to the quartz tube and heated under N2 atmosphere with a gas flow of 70mL/min. The quartz tube was heated with a constant rate of 25°C/min till the desired temperature and kept for 5h. After activation, the catalysts were passivated by passing a 1% oxygen/nitrogen mixture over the catalysts until no appreciable temperature rise was noted. The dried materials were then pelleted and crushed to particles about 20–40 mesh for evaluation. The catalyst derived from AHM and solid sulfur powder mixture was designated as HS-MoS2 while the catalyst derived from AHM and molten sulfur mixture was designated as HM-MoS2. The TM-MoS2 referred to catalyst prepared from ATM and molten sulfur mixture and the last T in TM-MoS2-T referred to the corresponding sulfidation temperature of the catalyst. 2.2 Catalysts characterization The N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms were measured on a Micromeritics Tristar-3000 instrument. Pore size distributions of the sample were determined from the isotherms by the BJH method. Fresh samples were vacuum dried first at 90°C for 1h and then at 300°C for about 3h before the adsorption measurement. The experimental error was ±3m2/g for the surface area, ±0.03cm3/g for the pore volume and ±0.2nm for the average pore size. The uncertainty was based on three independent runs for all samples. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained on a RigakuD/max-2500 X-ray diffractometer (40kV, 200mA) with a Ni-filtered Cu-Kα radiation source (λ =1.54056Å). The scan speed was 8°/min with a scanning angle that ranged from 10 to 90°. The phase identification was determined by comparison with the Joint Committee on Powder Diffraction Standards (JCPDS). The average particle size was determined using the Scherrer equation D = Kλ/B cos θ (K =0.89, λ =0.154). The experimental error was ±0.3nm for D XRD MoS 2 0 0 2 . The uncertainty was based on three independent runs for all samples. The high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) was performed on a JEOL JEM-2010F transmission electron microscope coupled with an electron dispersive X-ray (EDX) unit for elemental analysis. A small amount of sample was ground with a mortar and pestle. The sample was then suspended in ethanol and sonicated. A drop of the suspension was put on a lacey carbon film supported by a Cu grid. The sample was then transferred in a stream of N2 to a sample holder attached to the microscope. The distributions of MoS2 particle size and stacking number were calculated over 200–250 particles in several arbitrary chosen areas. The calculation error was ±0.8nm for the length, ±1 slab for the stacking, ±2 for the corresponding counts and ±0.4 for EDX measurement of S/Mo ratio. The uncertainty was based on three independent experiments for all samples. Laser Raman spectra (LRS) were recorded on a DXR Microscope spectrometer using the 532.0nm radiation line from a Spectra-Physics-2020 argon laser. The laser beam intensity and the spectrum slit width were 8mW and 25μm, respectively. The samples were pressed into pellets for the measurements. 2.3 Catalytic methanation activity evaluation The methanation performance of the catalyst (3mL) was evaluated in a fixed-bed reactor. The reaction temperature was monitored by a thermocouple put in the middle of the catalyst bed to ensure accurate temperature measurement. Prior to the reaction, the catalyst was re-sulfided in situ at 400°C for about 4h in a 100mL/min flow of 3% H2S/H2 mixture. Then the reactor was purged with the feed gas at a flow rate of 300mL/min (H2/CO ratio of 1.5, N2: 34.5vol.%, CH4: 8.5vol.% and H2S: 1.02vol.%, GHSV=6000h−1). The reactor temperature was increased to 550°C at a rate of 3°C/min and then pressurized to 3.0MPa. The outgas was condensed at a cold trap (−4°C) and the uncondensed gas was analyzed qualitatively by an Agilent 7890A GC system equipped with 2 sets of TCD and 1 set of FID for online analysis. The catalytic activity was represented by conversion of CO, selectivity of CH4 and yield of CH4, which were calculated according to the following formulas: X CO = F CO , in − F CO , out F CO , in × 100 % X H 2 = F H 2 , in − F H 2 , out F H 2 , in × 100 % S CH 4 = F CH 4 , out − F CH 4 , in F CO , in − F CO , out × 100 % S C 2 H 6 = 2 × ( F C 2 H 6 , out − F C 2 H 6 , in ) F CO , in − F CO , out × 100 % S CO 2 = F CO 2 , out − F CO 2 , in F CO , in − F CO , out × 100 % Y CH 4 = X CO × S CH 4 The experimental error was ±2% for conversion of CO and H2, ±0.5% for selectivities of CH4, CO2 and C2H6, and ±1% for yield of CH4. The uncertainty was based on three independent experiments. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Properties of as-prepared unsupported MoS2 catalysts From Table 1 we could see that for as-prepared catalysts, the surface area increased with the increase of sulfidation temperature despite of ammonium thiosalts precursors used, while the pore size was little affected by sulfidation temperature. Nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms of the MoS2 samples at variable sulfidation temperature were presented in Fig. 1 . The samples gave similar hysteresis loops to the H4 type, characteristic of mesopores typical for layered structures [37]. After the methanation test, the surface area of the sample increased, probably due to the sintering and growth of MoS2 crystallites. High sulfidation temperature yielded the catalyst with larger crystal size. EDX analysis (Table 2 ) showed that S/Mo atomic ratio on the catalyst decreased with the increase of sulfidation temperature, also it decreased greatly after the methanation reaction, implying the loss of some sulfur species during the reaction process. Treatment under different sulfidation temperature yielded MoS2 samples with variable crystallinity and textural structure. The XRD results were shown in Table 2 and Figs. 2 and 3 . For TM-MoS2 catalysts sulfided in the range of 400–550°C, only MoS2 phase was observed in the samples by powder X-ray diffraction. While not only MoS2 but traces of MoO2 were detected for AHM-derived catalysts at 400°C, and the MoO2 phase disappeared when the sulfidation temperature was above 450°C for HS-MoS2 catalyst. XRD patterns showed the expected narrowing of XRD peaks with the increase of sulfidation temperature, implying the amorphous MoS2 became well crystalline with the increase of sulfidation temperature. LRS results (Fig. 4 ) were presented also as a complementary to XRD. It showed that there was no difference on the species type for AHM-derived and ATM-derived MoS2 catalysts sulfided at 450°C. Some features at 100–250cm−l were observed on the Mo-based catalysts in some studies [38,39]. The peaks at 160–280cm−l were due to the vibration of MoMo bond [40]. The broadened line at about 377cm−l could be assigned to the existence of amorphous and/or very small crystallite of MoS2 [41] and the sharp peaks at 819cm−l and 992cm−l were both assigned to the MoO3 species which were generated during the passivation process. No evidence of additional sulfur species or intermediate states was present in this study. Narrowing of the XRD peaks was accompanied with an increase in the surface area and an increase of the length and stacking of MoS2 slabs. Statistical analysis of TEM images of the MoS2 slabs was shown in Figs. 5–7 . The MoS2 slabs in the samples were all straight which were quite different from MoS2 prepared without sulfur powder addition [42] and the stacks became more straight with the increase of sulfidation temperature. The BET surface areas were much larger and the stacks in bundles agglomerated at high temperature. Such coherence was also observed for AHM-derived MoS2 catalysts. Overall, the sulfidation temperature had a great effect on the morphological and structural property of MoS2. After the CO methanation test, the particle size of MoS2 increased to some extent and so did the crystallite degree of MoS2. 3.2 Effect of sulfidation temperature on the methanation activity Fig. 8 showed the methanation activity of unsupported MoS2 as a function of sulfidation temperature. It could be seen that the activity of as-prepared catalyst was enhanced by increasing sulfidation temperature and reached a maximum value at 450°C for the HS-MoS2 and TM-MoS2, respectively, except for the HM-MoS2. Further increase of the temperature led to a rapid decrease of the activity. While for HM-MoS2 catalyst, the activity decreased monotonously with the increase of sulfidation temperature. At low sulfidation temperature of 400°C, the HS-MoS2 exhibited approximately the same activity as HM-MoS2, but it exhibited much higher activity than the latter as the temperature was over 400°C. In the whole testing temperature range, the TM-MoS2 catalysts showed relatively better performance for methanation reaction than the other two catalysts even at a high sulfidation temperature (550°C). The reaction products over unsupported MoS2 catalysts were mainly CH4 and CO2 compounds with a small amount of C2H6 regardless of the sulfidation temperature and molybdenum salts used which was in agreement with the identification by Koizumi et al. [43]. Moreover, a similar trend for the selectivity and yield toward the formation of CH4 as a function of the sulfidation temperature was identified. It should be noted that with the increase of sulfidation temperature, the selectivity of CH4, CO2 and C2H6 did not vary much despite of the variation of CO conversion with temperature as shown in Fig. 8. According to the literature [44], the methanation reaction takes place on the Mo-based catalyst as follows: 2CO+2H2 →CH4 +CO2 The methanation reaction equilibrium data was calculated based on the thermodynamic properties under the reaction condition and was presented in Table 3 . It was seen that under the reaction temperature of 550°C, the CO equilibrium conversion was 93.23%. The fact that the CO conversion of TM-MoS2-450 was 89.77%, much close to the thermodynamic equilibrium value, indicated the high activity of this catalyst for methanation reaction. The catalytic stability of the HM-MoS2 and TM-MoS2 catalyst for CO methanation was also tested, as shown in Figs. 9 and 10 respectively. It could be seen that both two catalysts had high initial activity but a relatively poor stability. With the increase of the reaction time, the activity declined but the declining rate varied with various sulfidation temperatures. Clearly, a relatively better stability was achieved for catalyst sulfided at 450°C. Further increase of sulfidation temperature deteriorated not only the activity but the stability. 3.3 Structure–activity relationship 3.3.1 Sulfidation behavior of AHM and ATM The present study shows that using sulfur powder as sulfiding agent instead of toxic H2S can yield the catalyst with relatively high specific surface area as well as large pore volume, which are beneficial for the hydrotreating reaction. The as-prepared unsupported MoS2 catalysts exhibit high activity for methanation reaction. Comparatively, the ATM-derived MoS2 catalysts exhibit higher methanation activities than those of AHM-derived ones. The reason is considered to be the textural difference of two precursors. Decomposition of ATM can produce highly active MoS2 due to the structural similarities of ATM and the MoS2 as reported before [45]. CO methanation test in accompany with characterization results show that sulfidation behavior of AHM occurs quite differently from ATM. The synthesis of MoS2 from thermal decomposition of ATM under inert atmosphere involves the formation of MoS3, as previously reported [45], and then produces MoS2 upon heating: ATM (hydrated)→(NH4)2MoS4 →MoS3 →MoS2. Besides, it has been reported that the reduction of ATM seems to proceed only to the Mo (IV) stage in contrast to Al-supported catalysts that can reach lower Mo oxidation state [46]. While stable MoO2 species are detected by XRD in catalysts prepared from AHM at low temperature until the temperature reaches 550°C. It is thus speculated that the high decomposition temperature increases the degree of sulfidation and the increase in the crystallite of MoS2. Usually, it is considered that the decomposition of AHM is via the formation of MoO3, and then MoO3 undergoes a rapid reduction to MoO2 even at a moderate temperature [42,47]. But sulfidation of MoO2 to MoS2 is hard, which can be completed only at high temperature (>800°C) [31]. Based on these findings, it is no wonder to assume that the preparation from molten thiosalts involves the slight reduction of molybdenum thiosalts to MoO2 prior to sulfidation taking place. Whereas, the oxygen–sulfur exchanging energy barrier is reduced when the reduction is coincidence with sulfidation during the thermal decomposition for HS-MoS2, thus fully sulfidation can be completed at a relatively low temperature (450°C). 3.3.2 Effect of sulfidation temperature on the inherent structure of MoS2 The methanation evaluation results combined with BET results as a function of sulfidation temperature show that there is no correlation between surface area of the unsupported MoS2 catalysts and their activities. The increase in the surface area is probably due to the growth of MoS2 particles in high temperature. Textural properties and structures of the catalysts could be varied with sulfidation temperature. From the above characterization results, it is found that different sulfidation temperature may lead to the transformation of crystallite state and even different crystallite degree. In the temperature range of 400–450°C, the predominant species are 2H-MoS2 for TM-MoS2 samples. When the temperature rises to 550°C, MoS2 becomes the main species and trace amount of Mo3S4 is detected at 2θ =60.14°. While for AHM-derived MoS2 catalysts, 2H-MoS2 crystallites mainly existed on the sample sulfided at temperature range from 400°C to 550°C. After the methanation test, all catalysts are in the form of 2H-MoS2 species no matter what sulfidation temperature and precursors used. XRD profiles demonstrate that MoS2 is usually amorphous upon formation in relatively low sulfidation temperature [48,49], while it gets crystallized at sulfidation temperature larger than 550°C. So, amorphous MoS2 obtained at sulfidation temperature of 450°C favors the methanation reaction. EDX analysis shows that the S/Mo molar ratio of the fresh catalyst decreases with the increase of sulfidation temperature. Out of the expectation, the S/Mo ratio of AHM-derived catalyst is a little higher than that of ATM-derived MoS2, which implies that the activity also depends on other factors in addition to the sulfur to molybdenum ratio. 3.3.3 Deactivation of as-prepared unsupported MoS2 catalysts The above catalytic stability tests reveal that the as-prepared catalysts have high initial activity but poor stability. As we discussed above, different sulfidation temperature yields the catalyst with different crystal structure. So the inherent structure of MoS2 itself determines the methanation performance. The regular crystal structure formed in high sulfidation temperature causes the activity decrease of MoS2 catalyst as the increase of sulfidation temperature. What's more, Tanaka and his co-workers [50] shown that MoS2 crystallites grow three-dimensionally upon high-temperature sulfidation and this crystal growth of the MoS2 structure is a factor causing deactivation in laboratory test. Prada Silvy et al. [51] reported that the decrease in activity with increasing activation temperature on a CoMo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst could be due to the inflation of MoS2. The previous studies combined with our characterization results demonstrate that the growth of MoS2 crystallite with the increase of sulfidation temperature is another reason for the deactivation. Hexagonal MoS2 particles are found in our work (see Fig. 11 ), which was reported by Kasztelan et al. [52] as well. It is generally admitted that the active sites are located on the edges of the MoS2 slabs [53,27] and catalytic active sites are associated with sulfur vacancies on the edge sites formed under the reaction condition [54]. Thus more edges can make MoS2 catalyst possess more active sites, which results in a higher activity. From the TEM images in Fig. 5, we can see clearly that the slab length of MoS2 becomes short after the methanation reaction, and this means the decrease of the edge numbers. Besides, the S/Mo molar ratio for the TM-MoS2-450 is 2.47 before reaction and 1.91 after reaction, indicating that the loss of sulfur takes place during the methanation reaction. This sulfur loss also happens on the AHM-derived catalysts, similar to the findings on MoS2 supported on carbon by Ledoux et al. [55]. The loss of sulfur species is probably due to sulfur removal by the influence of CO adsorption [56] and the oxygen–sulfur exchange drawn by Topsøe et al. [57] on the one hand and the reduction of the edges on which the sulfur species exist on the other hand. It is thus speculated that the MoS2 slab length is greatly cut off by the reactive gases. In conclusion, the reason for the deactivation of the MoS2 catalyst with reaction time is probably the sulfur loss resulted from the reduction of the edges under the reaction conditions. 4 Conclusions The unsupported MoS2 catalysts could be prepared by thermal decomposition of AHM or ATM using sulfur powder instead of toxic H2S as sulfiding agent. Different sulfidation temperature yielded the catalyst with different crystallite state and structure. ATM-derived MoS2 is more active than AHM-derived MoS2 because of the structural similarity of ATM and MoS2. The amorphous MoS2 was favorable for methanation reaction. The catalytic activity and stability, textural structure, crystallinity and sulfidation degree of the AHM-derived MoS2 catalyst were greatly influenced by the sulfidation temperature. At sulfidation temperature of 450°C, the catalysts exhibit relatively the highest activity for CO methanation reaction. With the increase of sulfidation temperature, there exists a transition of MoS2 from amorphous state to crystallite state. The crystal growth of MoS2 particles and the inherent structure change with the increase of sulfidation temperature are probably the reasons for the activity decline. The deactivation of unsupported MoS2 catalyst with reaction time may be due to the loss of surface sulfur resulted from the reduction of the edges during the reaction process. coredata.dc:description: Unsupported MoS2 catalysts were obtained by thermal decomposition of ammonium tetrathiomolybdate (ATM) or ammonium heptamolybdate (AHM) using sulfur powder as sulfiding agent at variable sulfidation temperature (400–550°C). The CO conversion, selectivity and yield of CH4 on the catalysts were studied for the methanation reaction. It was found that CO conversion increased with temperature rise at first, reached maximum value at sulfidation temperature of 450°C and then decreased sharply with further increase of temperature. The catalyst derived from ATM could get higher CO conversion than the catalyst from AHM because of the structural similarity between ATM and MoS2. XRD analysis demonstrated that amorphous MoS2 was favorable for the methanation reaction and a crystal transition of MoS2 nanoparticle happened during the methanation reaction. The higher the sulfidation temperature was, the more easily regular crystal structure of MoS2 formed. TEM characterization results showed that at the optimum sulfidation temperature of 450°C, the length and stacking degree of MoS2 crystallite were the highest and so more active sites could reside on the edges of MoS2 slabs for CO methanation. The crystal growth of MoS2 particle and its structure change are probably the reasons for the deactivation of the MoS2 catalysts with the increase of sulfidation temperature. In addition, it is the loss of surface sulfur that caused deactivation of the catalyst with reaction time.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of sulfidation temperature on the catalytic behavior of unsupported MoS2 catalysts for synthetic natural gas production from syngas
